pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:0.2: The nuns’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing suspension
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:0.4: 2. The training rule on one who gives the full admission to a criminal
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.2: At that time in Vesālī the wife of a certain Licchavī man was unfaithful.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.4: “Please stop. If you don’t, I’ll punish you.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.6: Just then in Vesālī the Licchavī clan had gathered on some business.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.7: That Licchavī man said to them,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.8: “Sirs, please give me permission in regard to one of my wives.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.10: “She’s unfaithful. I wish to kill her.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.13: that her husband wanted to kill her,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.14: she took their most valuable possessions and went to Sāvatthī. There she went to the monastics of other religions and asked for the going forth,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.16: She then went to the Buddhist nuns and again asked for the going forth,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.18: She then went to the nun Thullanandā, showed her the goods, and once again asked for the going forth.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.19: Thullanandā took the goods and gave her the going forth.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.20: That Licchavī man then went to Sāvatthī in search of his wife. When he saw that she had been given the going forth as a nun, he went to King Pasenadi of Kosala
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.22: “Sir, my wife took my most valuable possessions and came to Sāvatthī.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.23: Please permit me to deal with her.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.24: “Well then, find her and then inform me.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.25: “I’ve seen her. She’s gone forth as a nun.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.26: “If she’s gone forth as a nun, there’s nothing that can be done.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.27: The Teaching of the Buddha is well-proclaimed. Let her practice the spiritual life for the full ending of suffering.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.28: Then that Licchavī man complained and criticized the nuns,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.29: “How could the nuns give the going forth to a criminal?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.30: The nuns heard the complaints of that Licchavī man,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.31: and the nuns of few desires complained and criticized her,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.32: “How could Venerable Thullanandā give the going forth to a criminal?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.34: “Is it true, monks, that the nun Thullanandā did this?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.37: “How could the nun Thullanandā give the going forth to a criminal?
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.39: “And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule like this:
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.40.1: ‘If a nun, without getting permission from the king or the Sangha or a community or an association or a society, gives the full admission to a woman who she knows is a criminal and who is known as sentenced to death, then, except when it is allowable, that nun too has committed an immediate offense entailing sending away and suspension.’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.4: … The nun who has been given the full ordination in unanimity by both Sanghas through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of nun is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.6: she knows by herself or others have told her or she has told her.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.7: A woman who is a criminal:
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.8: any woman who has stolen anything worth five _māsakas_ coins or more is called “a criminal”.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.10: she has been sentenced to death because of her action.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.12: it is known to other people that she has been sentenced to death.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.16: where a king reigns, permission should be obtained from the king.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.18: what is meant is the Sangha of nuns, and permission should be obtained from that Sangha.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.20: where a community governs, permission should be obtained from that community.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.22: where an association governs, permission should be obtained from that association.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.24: where a society governs, permission should be obtained from that society.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.28: there are two allowable situations: she has gone forth with monastics of another religion or she has gone forth with other Buddhist nuns.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.29: If, intending to give the full admission, she searches for a group, a teacher, a bowl, or a robe, or she establishes a monastery zone, then, except when it is allowable, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.30: After the motion, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.31: After each of the first two announcements, she commits a serious offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.32: When the last announcement is finished, the preceptor commits an offense entailing suspension,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.33: and the group and the teacher commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.35: this is said with reference to the preceding offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.37: there is an offense as soon as the misconduct is committed, and no pressing is required.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.39: she is sent away from the Sangha.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.41: … Therefore, too, it is called an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.2.1: If she is a criminal, and the nun perceives her as such, and she gives her the full admission, except when it is allowable, she commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.2.2: If she is a criminal, but the nun is unsure of it, and she gives her the full admission, except when it is allowable, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.2.3: If she is a criminal, but the nun does not perceive her as such, and she gives her the full admission, except when it is allowable, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.2.4: If she is not a criminal, but the nun perceives her as such, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.2.5: If she is not a criminal, but the nun is unsure of it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.2.6: If she is not a criminal, and the nun does not perceive her as such, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.3.2: if she gives her the full admission without knowing that she is a criminal;
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.3.3: if she gives her the full admission after getting permission;
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.3.4: if she gives her the full admission when it is allowable;
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.3.6: if she is the first offender.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.3.7: The second offense entailing suspension is finished.
